definitions.definition: To enclose (an object) completely in any flexible, thin material such as fabric or paper .
examples: Christmas gifts are commonly known to be wrapped in paper.

definitions.definition: To enclose or coil around an object or organism, as a form of grasping .
examples: A snake wraps itself around its prey.

definitions.definition: To conceal by enveloping or enfolding; to hide.
To finish shooting (filming) a video, television show, or movie.
To break a continuous line (of text) onto the next line
examples: I wrapped the text so that I wouldn't need to scroll to the right to read it.

definitions.definition: To make functionality available through a software wrapper .
To (cause to) reset to an original value after passing a maximum.
examples: The row counter wraps back to zero when no more rows can be inserted.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To enclose (an object) completely in any flexible, thin material such as fabric or paper .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To enclose or coil around an object or organism, as a form of grasping .
( transitive , figurative ) To conceal by enveloping or enfolding; to hide.
( transitive or intransitive , video production ) To finish shooting (filming) a video, television show, or movie.
( transitive , lines, words, text, etc. ) To break a continuous line (of text) onto the next line
( computing , transitive ) To make functionality available through a software wrapper .
( transitive or intransitive ) To (cause to) reset to an original value after passing a maximum.
